list.item: ACT I A street in the city of Bethulia .
SCENE I . The valley near the Assyrian camp . Time , morning ; two days later .
SCENE II . The tent of Holofernes . Time , later , the same morning .
SCENE III . The same . Time , the same night .
SCENE I . Same as Act I . Time , later , the same night .

div.head: ACT I

stage.stage: A street in the city of Bethulia in Judea . Bethulia is in the hill country , overlooking the great plain of Jezreel to the south-west . Back , the gates of the city , hiding the view of the plain . Right , Judith 's house , with a tent on the roof . Left , houses . The street turns abruptly , back left , along the wall of the city . Left centre , a built-up vantage-point , from which the plain can be seen over the gates .

sp.speaker: TIME
sp.p: Fifth century B. C . Towards evening . Ozias is standing alone in the street , drinking from a leathern bottle . Enter Chabris , back left .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: quickly , but with perfect calmness , hiding the bottle in his garmentsOld man ! It is years since I saw you . How came you past the guard , old man ?

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: Old ? Old ? I am not yet a hundred . Who are you ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Ozias .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: Ah ! So this is Ozias , the son of Ezbon . Before your father could walk I have nursed him on my knee ; and he was filled like the full moon — with naughtiness .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: What has brought you at last out of your house ? Are you come to prophesy once more ?

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: I have given up prophesying .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: A profession full of risks .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: I pass my endless days in meditation and solitude .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: That sounds much safer . How comely is the wisdom of old men !

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: And what do you do , sprig ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Has none told you ?

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: I see nobody but my daughter 's granddaughter , and her I forbid to speak to me , because being a woman she has the tongue of a woman , and a woman 's tongue is unfavourable to meditation . How should I be told ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: I am the governor of this great city of Bethulia .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: You are responsible for this city ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: I am .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: Now I understand my misfortune . And the truth was in me when I said to your mother as she lay dying : Better it is to die without children than to have them that are ungodly .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Oh ! How comely a thing is the judgment of grey hairs !

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: You ask me what has brought me at last out of my house . I will tell you . Thirst ! Thirst has brought me out of my house . Every morning and every evening my great-grandchild serves me with pulse and water . For five days she has furnished less and less water , and this day — not a drop ! Can one eat pulse without water to drink ? Half an hour ago I went to her to reason with her , and she lay on her bed cracked , and raved that she herself had not drunk for three days and that there was no water left in all Bethulia . So I came at last out of my house into the streets of this city famous for its cool fountains which never fail . And lo ! I meet the governor of this city , and he is Ozias ! Ozias ! Seven days do men mourn for him that is dead , but for an ungodly man all the days of his life ! Why is there no water in Bethulia , sprig ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Old man , meditation is good and solitude is good , but think not because you sit staring all day at your own belly that the sun and stars have ceased to revolve round the earth and the kings of this world to make war . Is it possible that you do not know what has happened ?

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: I only know that I cannot eat pulse without water to drink .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Bethulia is besieged .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: Who is besieging Bethulia ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Holofernes .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: I have never heard his name . Who is he ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Never heard the name of the chief captain of Nebuchadnezzar ? Have you heard the name of Nebuchadnezzar , by chance ?

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: I seem to remember it .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Come up here .They go up the steps to the vantage-point .Look ! A hundred and twenty thousand foot-soldiers . Twelve thousand archers on horseback . Oxen and sheep for their provisions . Twenty thousand asses for their carriages . Camels without number . Infinite victuals ; and very much gold and silver . The like was never seen before .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: stepping down .Why has Nebuchadnezzar set about this thing ? What harm has Bethulia done to him ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Much harm . Nebuchadnezzar has decided to be God . He has decreed that all nations and tribes shall call upon him as God . And he has conquered the whole earth , excepting only Judea ; and Bethulia is the gate into Judea , and Bethulia has not listened to his decree , and I am the governor of Bethulia . So Nebuchadnezzar the great king is very angry and Holofernes is the tool of his wrath .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: going up the steps again and gazing .How many did you say ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: A hundred and twenty thousand foot and twelve thousand horse .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: At any rate this will be the last war .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: Why ! Because plainly war cannot continue on such a scale . Or if it does , mankind is destroyed . Nebuchadnezzar has rendered war ridiculous .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: laughs ; then half to himself , sarcasticallyWhat is heavier than lead , and what is the name thereof , but an aged fool ?

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: descending again , self-centredIt remains that I cannot eat pulse without water to drink .To Ozias .And surely Bethulia has more wells than any other city of Judea .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: The wells are at the foot of the hills , and Holofernes has seized them all .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: That is not fighting .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: It is war .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: No , no ! In my time soldiers fought fairly .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: And killed each other . Why should Holofernes sacrifice thousands of lives to take the heights when he can reach the same result by letting his men sit still and watch ?

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: I say this is not war . Once I travelled many days to Nineveh . It is a city of extravagance , and when I beheld its mad , new-fangled ways , I knew that the last day was nigh . I was right . Three thousand and five hundred years since Jehovah created Adam , and Eve from his rib ... Too long ! Too long ! And what is pulse without water ? I must have water .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: It is thirty-four days since Holofernes took the wells . If you have received water up to yesterday your great-grandchild must indeed have thirsted that you might drink . I have distributed water by measure , but now the cisterns are empty , and women and young men fall down in the streets , and there is no water in Bethulia . We are all in like case , the high and the lowly .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: Then give me your bottle .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: What bottle ?

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: I saw you put it from your lips as I came .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: It behoves you to understand , old man , that my solemn duty as governor is to maintain my own strength , for if I fell the city would fall . Without me to inspire them the populace would yield in a moment . What is the populace ? Poltroons , animals , sheep , rabbits , insects , lice !

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: Give me the bottle .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: It is as empty as the cisterns .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: Give it to me , or I will cry through the streets that you are concealing water .Ozias gives him the bottle . Chabris drinks . Ozias snatches the bottle away and conceals it .Ah !

div.stage: A figure is glimpsed in the tent on the roof of Judith 's house . Ozias starts .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: What is that up yonder ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Nothing .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: Whose house is this ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: It is the house of Judith , the daughter of Merari .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: Ah ! Merari , the son of Ox , the son of Oziel — Oziel and I were little playful boys together — the son of Elcia , the son of Raphaim , the son of Eliab , the son of Nathanael , the son of ——

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Old man , your memory is terrible . Have pity !

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: The draught has revived me . So Merari married and had a daughter . What manner of woman is she ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: She is the widow of Manasses , who died of the heat in the barley harvest . And she is childless . And she is very rich ; for Manasses left her gold and silver and menservants and maid-servants and cattle and lands . And she has remained a widow in her house three years and four months , and never has she come forth . And there is none to give her an ill word , for she fears the Lord greatly .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: Yes . But what manner of woman is she ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: She is beautiful to behold .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: to himselfOh ! That manner of woman !

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: And she has fasted all the days of her widowhood , except the eves of the Sabbaths and the Sabbaths , and the eves of the new moons and the new moons , and the feasts and solemn days of the House of Israel .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: You are most deeply versed in her life . Is she exceeding beautiful ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: She is exceeding beautiful .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: Then it was she who peepedwith a peculiar emphasis on the wordfrom the tent a moment since .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Old man , you have eyes .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: It is the draught of water .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: She is said to take the air in her tent daily at this hour .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: accusinglyAnd that is why you are here , Ozias .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: No ! I come here to reflect upon my plans for the saving of the city , and because of this vantage-point , to view the army of the Assyrians .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: This vantage-point is new since my day . You have built it here , not to see the Assyrians , but to see Judith . And that is why you have set a guard to keep the street empty .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: And if it be so , what then ? Old man , you are so old that to confess in your ear is sweet , like murmuring secrets into the grave . If I do come to this place to watch for the marvellous vision of Judith , what then ?

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: What then ? And the populace of Bethulia dying of thirst ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: The populace !... Mice ! Rats ! Beetles !He makes the motion of crushing with his foot .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: Yet the city is doomed . You can have no hope .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: No hope ? Am I then a dead body ? Am I a rotting corpse ? True , the city will be taken , and when the city is taken I may be killed . But in your meditations , old man , has it not occurred to you that death must be highly interesting ? Or I may be seized for a slave . But either I should cease speedily to be a slave , or I should become the most powerful slave in Babylon .Reflectively .We might be enslaved together .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: Who ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Judith and I . The history of the world is full of miracles . Meanwhile , I live , and the strong savour of life inflames my nostrils ; and the ever-increasing magnificence and terror of war is like wine in my mouth . I shake with delight at the vastness and the mystery of the future .... And there is woman !

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: I feel I can eat my pulse now .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: There is still woman . A fracas is heard , back . Enter Rahel , running , followed by two soldiers and a mixed group of Bethulians , including Charmis , an elder .

sp.speaker: RAHEL
sp.p: to Chabris , like a termagantWhy did you go forth alone , grandad , frightening me when I looked and could not find you ? At your age ! Come back with me this moment .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: Ay ! There is still woman !

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: angrily , to first soldierDid I not give an order to bar the street ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: My lord , some of these are elders of high authority , and would pass . As for the girl ——

sp.speaker: RAHEL
sp.p: to ChabrisThis moment !She faints and falls .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: indifferently , as Charmis moves towards RahelLet her lie . She will come to of herself — or not , as God wills .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: to the soldiers , with cold fiercenessGet back to your places .Exeunt soldiers .

sp.speaker: CHARMIS
sp.p: looking at Ozias and indicating RahelShe is the fourteenth I have seen faint from thirst in the streets this day .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: soothinglyAlas ! And you or I may be the next . We are all in like case . But what is to be done ?

div.stage: Confused feeble exclamations from the group of citizens : ‘ We want to know . We are come for that . There is but one thing to be done . ’

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: still soothinglyWho among you will be the spokesman ?

sp.speaker: CHARMIS
sp.p: We are all spokesmen .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Even the children ?

sp.speaker: CHARMIS
sp.p: Even the children . In our extremity we are all spokesmen .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: But not all at once . Will you begin , honourable Charmis ? You know that I am the servant of the citizens .

sp.speaker: CHARMIS
sp.p: nervously oratoricalLord Ozias , may the God of Israel judge between us and you , for you have done us a great injury .Looks round for approval . The group approves .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: An injury ? I ? Have I not said that I am the servant of the citizens ?

sp.speaker: CHARMIS
sp.p: more confidentlyAnd I say again that you have done us a great injury , in that you have not asked peace of the Assyrians . For we have no helper , and the God of Israel has sold us into the hands of the Assyrians . We are thrown down before them with thirst and with great destruction . Therefore now we demand —looks round— I say we demand that you call the Assyrians , and deliver the whole city for a spoil to the people of Holofernes and to all his army . For it is better for us to be made a spoil than to die of thirst . We will be the slaves of Holofernes , so that our souls may live and so that we may not see the death of our infants before our eyes , nor our wives nor our children die .A mother in the group convulsively seizes her child . Pause . Ozias walks about .We take to witness against you the heaven and the earth and our God and the God of our fathers , which punishes us according to our sins and the sins of our fathers ; and we demand of you that you deliver up the city to Holofernes and his host .A silence .

div.stage: Ozias ascends solemnly to the vantage-point .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: dominating the assemblyFriends , it would seem that Charmis has made an end . His words are excellent and full of pity . Who follows him ? Who will speak next ? My ear waits .A silence .Ah ! Then give heed . The words of Charmis are full of pity , but I also have pity . Do not I too cherish our women , and our maidens and our young children ? And because I pity I would not yield to the monster Holofernes . Yes , the monster ! This is not war that he wages . Once our enemy strove fairly with the warriors of Israel . Now he makes our women and children to die of thirst . The magnificence of war is gone from the earth , and Holofernes by the excess of his hosts has rendered war ridiculous .Chabris raises his hands .The peoples of the earth will perceive that henceforward the institution of war cannot continue , and after this there will be no more war . But meanwhile , if I go crouching to the feet of Holofernes , what will happen and what will come to pass ? Surely it will come to pass that the monster who has sat down to watch us die of thirst will slay our little children and our old men , and dishonour our women , and ravish our innocent virgins ; for the enslaving of the conquered will not content his anger nor satisfy the lust of his great hosts . Shall these things be ? I say they shall not be . But what am I , save the servant of the citizens of Bethulia ? And what do I speak , save the thought that is in your hearts ? There is no cowardice in you . You are not sheep , nor rabbits , nor beetles , nor lice . You are valiant men , and women lion-hearted . Without you I am naught , and if I defy Holofernes , my fortitude is yours and my resolve springs from you . Charmis has invoked the holy name of the God of Israel . Let Israel not forget its God , for never has the Most High forsaken Israel . Brethren , be of good courage . Let us yet endure five days . Five short days . And if these days pass and the God of Israel turn not his mercy towards us , then will I do according to the word of Charmis . Such is my oath to you . And so it shall be . Haggith enters from the house of Judith .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: My lord Ozias !

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: quickly descending the stepsWhat say you ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: My mistress , the lady Judith , will speak with you . She comes .

sp.speaker: RAHEL
sp.p: half risingWater !

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: excited .The lady Judith comes out of her house after three years .

sp.speaker: VOICES IN THE GROUP
sp.p: excited and impressed .Judith is coming , after three years ! Judith ! The widow !

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: sternly to the groupGet hence , everyone to his own charge . Soldiers ! Clear the street !Two soldiers advance , running to obey .The men to the walls and towers . The women and children to their houses .To Rahel , who has risen , indicating Chabris .Take the aged fool away , girl .Ruthlessly and contemptuously .Get home , all of you . Rabble ! Insects ! Lice !The street is cleared , not without difficulty , and Ozias is left alone with Haggith .After a pause , Judith enters slowly , in widow 's apparel and sackcloth .

div.stage: Exit Haggith into the house .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Greetings , Lord Ozias .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Lady , greetings .They salute .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Where are the people ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: I invited them to go away .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Your waiting-woman said that you would speak with me .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: But what I have to say I would have said before them .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Forgive your servant .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: No ! It is I , the woman , who should ask to be absolved .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: I beseech you ——

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: simplyPerhaps you dismissed the people because it is not meet for them to see all the workings of the mind which has authority over them .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: warmly responsiveAh ! Lady ! In your wisdom and your understanding you have comprehended what it is to be the governor of a besieged city . You , alone !

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: This is a day memorable beyond all the days of Bethulia .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: It is a day memorable beyond all the days of Bethulia — because Judith , the widow of Manasses , has issued from her house and from her secrecy , and because after long years she has lightened the city with her countenance .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: smilingWe hold converse with words , but the shadow of destruction is over us , and our hearts are darkened , and we hide our hearts in speech . Ozias , governor of Bethulia , show me your heart .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: I dare not .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Dare ! I am not afraid .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: YOU are more beautiful than aforetime — were it possible .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: accepting the complimentAnd if I am ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: That is what is in my heart ! Behold my heart , and the depths of my heart . Look deep , and deeper , and still you will see naught therein but the beauty and the subtlety of Judith .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: It is no common man that with the parched tongue of thirst can talk thus while unspeakable calamity assails the city .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: It is Ozias .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: gentlyI came not to meet Ozias , but the governor of Bethulia . From my tent I hearkened to the words which he spoke to the people , and the Lord said to me : Go down to him , thou , a woman . And I am here .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: The Lord reigns ! That which I said to the people did not please the ear of Judith ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: I spoke to the people according to their understanding . Have you not said it is not meet for the people to know the thoughts of the ruler ? Hearken again ? And I will speak now to the wise woman . I flattered the people with vain praise of their courage , when they have no courage . I affrighted the people with a prophecy of terror , when there is no terror — for Holofernes is a great warrior , and has compassion in his greatness , for he is a Babylonian . I gave them hope of succour when succour is none — for , with a hundred and twenty thousand footmen and twelve thousand horse against uswith dry humourto count upon the mercy of the Lord is presumption .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: moves aside and returns . SweetlyWhy then did you speak thus to the people ? And to what end did you deceive them ? I beseech you yet again to show me your heart , for it is right that I should know .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: I saw the vastness of the future as in a vision . If the God of Israel perchance is merciful , and the city is saved at the eleventh hour , then it will be said in Jerusalem that there is none like Ozias of Bethulia for steadfastness , for he alone by his ardour revived the fainting populace and held firm the city ; and great will be my recompense .... But that is a dream . Always I have faced the substance of things , and the substance is that Nebuchadnezzar has decreed to rule over the whole earth , and from the east to the west there is no living man that shall not bow down before Nebuchadnezzar . Bethulia will fall . I , the governor , shall be taken captive and shown to Nebuchadnezzar , and in that day Holofernes shall say to Nebuchadnezzar : Lo ! Here is Ozias the Israelite who resisted thy mighty armies for thirty-four days and yet five days more . Use him if it seem good to thee . And I shall be lifted up to be a satrap of Nebuchadnezzar , and I shall partake of the bright glory of Nebuchadnezzar . And —hesitates .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: subtly and sweetlyAnd ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: in an outburstWhat am I without you , O Judith ? Before Manasses loved you , did I not love you ? For three years have I not watched over you in all honour and respect , and troubled you not with my importunity until this day , which is the day of days ? What am I without you , and what shall be my dominion and my satrap 's throne if you do not sit in majesty by my side , O Rose of Sharon and matchless among women ? Judithas beforeMy lord , you are like a rushing river .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: You have seen my heart .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: I have seen it .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: And what say you ? There is the sudden sound of a disturbance . Enter , from back , soldiers , holding Achior , and a group of excited citizens . Haggith appears at the house-door .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: fiercelyWhat ! Are my commands no more than the wind in the corn , and is there to be naught but tumult within the walls of this city ?

sp.speaker: VOICES IN THE GROUP
sp.p: An Assyrian ! An Assyrian !

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: Lord Ozias ! We saw this man lying bound at the foot of the hill , and we descended and loosed him and brought him privily into Bethulia by the secret way . And now we present him to my lord .

sp.speaker: OZIAS F
sp.p: ools ! Then no longer is the secret way secret .

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: Slay him ! Stone him ! Whip the dog !

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: nobly scornful , to the crowdOh ! Brave ! Oh ! Men of courage and high valour !

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: to AchiorWho are you ?

sp.speaker: ACHIOR
sp.p: Achior .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Your condition ?

sp.speaker: ACHIOR
sp.p: with calm , genial candourCaptain of all the Ammonites in the army of Holofernes .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Let them loose him , Lord Ozias . His eyes are not the eyes of treachery .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: to the soldiersLoose him .To Achior .And how come you here ? Speak the truth — and fear .

sp.speaker: ACHIOR
sp.p: My mouth shall say truth , but I will not fear .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: My hand is terrible .

sp.speaker: ACHIOR
sp.p: Thus it happened . When the children of Israel had shut up the passages of the hill country and had fortified all the tops of the high hills , Holofernes was very angry . And he called the captains of Ammon and said to them : Tell me now , ye sons of Chanaan , who these Israelites are that dwell in the hill country , and wherein is their power and strength , and why they have determined not to come and meet me , more than all the inhabitants of the west ? And I , Achior , answered the question of Holofernes .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: And what answer gave you ?

sp.speaker: ACHIOR
sp.p: I said to Holofernes : This people is descended of the Chaldeans . But they left the way of their ancestors and would not follow the gods of their fathers ; and they worshipped the God of heaven . So they were cast out from the face of the gods of Chaldea , and they fled into Mesopotamia . And they came to Chanaan . But when a famine covered all the land of Chanaan they went down into Egypt , and the king of Egypt brought them low with labouring in brick and made them slaves . Then they cried to their God , and he smote all the land of Egypt with plagues .... And God dried the Red Sea for them .

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: It is true . It is true !

sp.speaker: ACHIOR
sp.p: And they came to Chanaan , and drove before them the inhabitants of that land , and they dwelt in that country many days . And while they sinned not before their God they prospered , because the God that hates iniquity was with them .

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: It is true .

sp.speaker: ACHIOR
sp.p: But when they departed from the way which their God appointed , then they were destroyed in many battles very sore , and were led captives into a land that was not theirs , and the temple of their God was cast to the ground .

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: Gentile dog ! Shall we not render him to pieces ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: There is but one truth , brethren , whether it please or whether it displease .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: to AchiorMake an end .

sp.speaker: ACHIOR
sp.p: And I said to Holofernes : But now this people are returned to their God , and have possessed Jerusalem , and are seated in the hill country .With more emphasis .And I said further to Holofernes : Now therefore , my lord and governor , if there be any error in this people , let us go up and we shall overcome them . But if there be no iniquity in their nation , let my lord now pass by , lest their Lord defend them and we become a reproach before all the world .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: It was well said .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Lady , it was well said — if the slave said it .To Achior .I demanded of you : How came you here ?

sp.speaker: ACHIOR
sp.p: Thus . When I had finished speaking to Holofernes , all they that were about my lord and governor rose up in wrath and cried : Kill him . And the face of Holofernes darkened , and he said : And who art thou , Achior , that thou hast prophesied among us to-day that we should not make war with the people of Israel because of their God ? And who is God but Nebuchadnezzar ? Nebuchadnezzar by my hand will destroy the Israelites , and their God shall not deliver them . Their mountains shall be drunken with their blood and their fields shall be filled with their dead bodies .The citizens show alarm .And thou , Achior , shalt be delivered up to the Israelites in Bethulia , and when thou seest me again thou shalt fall among the slain .... And he commanded his servants , and they took me , and carried me secretly to the foot of the hill of Bethulia . And here am I !

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: after a pause , positivelyIt is a wicked device for our undoing .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: How so ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Plainly this fellow lies , and he has come subtly with a tale to spy out our strength . Presently he will seek to escape from us again to the Assyrians .

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: Spy ! Stone him ! Rend him !

sp.speaker: ACHIOR
sp.p: to OziasTo Holofernes , my lord and governor , I spoke truth ; and to you also I speak truth . Never has my mouth lied , nor my tongue uttered deceit . If death is ordained for my recompense , so be it .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: to OziasHe is a fair youth , and has spoken truly and feared not .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: with meaningLady , he is a fair youth , and fearless . But by what sign know you that he has spoken truly ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: By the glance of his eyes I know .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: It is a sign that suffices not . Shall it be said that Ozias was deceived , and shall Ozias imperil his renown , by reason of the glance of a youth when he looks at a woman — even you ?... And if he lies not , then he is a fool and his folly was great .

sp.speaker: ACHIOR
sp.p: I spoke the truth to Holofernes .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: fiercelyBut to speak truth did not content you . Having answered Holofernes , you must needs offer counsel to your lord and governor ! Who were you to offer counsel to the greatest of all the captains of the earth ? The protection of the mighty conqueror covered you , and lo ! in your folly did you estrange yourself from him . Fool !

sp.speaker: ACHIOR
sp.p: I said to Holofernes , my lord and governor , that which I was appointed to say — that , no more and no less .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: And who appointed you to say that which you said ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: If there be a God in Israel , and if the Lord has not abandoned us , may not this youth be the messenger of the Most High to bring us comfort , and for a warning to the vainglory of Holofernes ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: with ironyAll is possible to the Lord . Yet may his purposes be hidden from us .To the soldiers .Until the Lord vouchsafe new wisdom to me , his servant , bind fetters about the feet of Achior , and take him to the house of bondage , and set a guard over him , for a spy is not more dangerous than a fool .

sp.speaker: CHARMIS
sp.p: springing forwardIt shall be done , Ozias .

div.stage: The soldiers begin to put chains on Achior .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: quietlyShame him not with fetters , lord Ozias .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: after a pause , to the soldiersUnbind him !The soldiers obey .Take him off ! Speedily ! Away ! All ! Let none remain ! Hasten , I say !

div.stage: Exeunt back , all except Ozias and Judith . As he goes Achior kisses Judith 's robe .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: to Achior , as he does soTruth-teller !

div.stage: At a sign from Judith , Haggith re-enters the house .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Your face is turned from me , because of the youth . Yet you came out to see the governor of the city , and the governor could do no other than I have done .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: looking at himOzias , you have shown me your heart .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Yea !

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: And in the moment when the youth came you asked of me my counsel .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Yea !

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Hear me now , for the words you have spoken before the people this day are not right .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: What words ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: This promise that you have uttered to deliver the city to our enemies , unless within five days the Lord turn to help . Who are you that seek to stand instead of God among the children of men ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Stand instead of God !

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Who are you that have tempted God this day ? For you cannot find the depth of the heart of man ,— how then shall you search out God or comprehend his purpose ? Brother , provoke not the Lord our God to anger . For if he will not help us within these five days , he has power to defend us when he will , even every day . Do not bind the counsels of God . For God is not as man that he may be threatened , neither as the son of man that he should be wavering . Therefore let us wait for salvation from him , and he will hear our voice ,— if it please him . Moreover , this city is the key and the gateway to all Judea . If it be obstinate in resistance , Judea is not defiled , but if it be taken the whole land shall lie waste and God will require the profanation of it at our mouth .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: All that you have spoken is truth , and there is none to gainsay your words . From the beginning of your days we have known your wisdom , and your understanding is manifest ....With significance .But we are thirsty .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: If we are thirsty , let us give thanks to the Lord our God , who tries us , even as he did our fathers .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: The people in the extremity of their thirst compelled me to an oath , which I will not break .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Say you the people , Ozias ? As for them , you hold them lightly , and they are as naught in your eyes . So much you have avowed .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: in a new toneIt is true . This day I hold the people lightly . But when the great madness and desperation of thirst comes at last upon them , who shall hold them ? In that day they will seize the things forbidden , and they will drink the wine sanctified and reserved for the priests that serve the Lord . And to avert from me the wrath of Joachim , the high priest of Jerusalem , I have sent already a messenger to Jerusalem to bring a licence that this matter may be lawful .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: shockedNay !

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: I say it will be so .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: It shall not be so .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Then pray you to the Most High for the city , even for all of us , and the Lord will send rain for our cisterns and we shall faint no more . Pray , for you are a godly woman , and the God of Israel shall listen .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: with supreme impressivenessHear me again , Ozias . This night I will do a thing which shall go throughout all the generations to the children of Israel . You shall stand this night in the gate of the city , and I will go forth from the city with my waiting-woman ; and within the days that you have promised to deliver the city to our enemies the Lord will visit Israel by my hand .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: On what errand will you go ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Enquire not of my act , for I will not declare it until the things are finished that I do . But this I declare , that the Lord has inclined himself to me , and now he has sent Achior for a sign .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: You go to Holofernes !

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: To Holofernes .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Do not go !

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: But why shall I not go ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: The perils of the heathen will surround you , and harm will surely befall you , for Holofernes will work lamentable evil upon you . And I cannot suffer it .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: smilingDid not Ozias say that Holofernes was a great warrior and had compassion in his greatness ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: insistentI cannot suffer it , for if any shame come upon you I will not live .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: God will not see his handmaid shamed . Moreover I regard not myself in this thing , but the welfare of the people of Israel .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: kneelingJudith , I entreat you ! For you are the light of my eyes , and without you the world is not .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: softlyI know it . Think you that in these years I have not seen the depths of your heart , Ozias ? Think you that I was blind in my tent ? Think you that I watched not upon you ? You were comely in my sight . But this day you have revealed your pride . For you seek not God , but the vanity of the earth , and you would make all Israel the instrument of your glory , denying the Lord . And I am sad .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Forgive me , Rose of Sharon .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: softlyWho am I , to forgive my brother ? Peace be upon you !She turns towards her house .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: rising ,Stay !

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: I go to prepare myself for that which I have to do .Exit into the house .

div.stage: A soldier shows himself , back .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Friend !

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: approaching and salutingLord ! Your command !

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Send to me the officer of the watch .

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: Lord , the honourable lieutenant lies sick .

div.stage: Haggith appears at the door of the house .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Thirst has overcome him ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: bowingHe raves on the bed , lord , and his tongue is like the tongue of a dog .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Who then commands the watch by the watchfires this night ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: I , lord . The watchfires wait the torch .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Will you , too , faint , and will your tongue be like the tongue of a dog ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: grimly, Not mine , lord .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: DO the people complain ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: Lord , they whine and snivel mightily .

div.stage: Enter Haggith with a small sack .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Is the secret way shut ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: Shut and barred , lord .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: It must be opened .... Stand ! I will see to it .

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: AS my lord wills .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Has the watch aught to drink ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: My lord knows that no drop is left in the gourds .

div.stage: Ozias waves him away , and he retires .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: to Haggith , who is busy with the sackWoman , has the lady Judith perchance dreamed a dream ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: enigmaticallyMy mistress has dreamed no dream . Why does the lord Ozias ask ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: It seemed to me —stops

div.stage: The soldier strolls forward . Twilight begins to fall .
Enter Haggith from the house with more baggage .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: to the soldier ; curtly ; not looking at himSo thou hast no water ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: with genial freedomYea , Haggith , we have still a little .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: Then thou has lied to the governor ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: Him ?With a jerk of the shoulder !He knows ! In truth now , thinkest thou he would expect us soldiers to keep guard without water ? He knows ! But he is a great lord , and in seemliness he asks for a lie , and that which he asks is given to him — in seemliness .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: But the officer raving as thou hast said with thirst ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: Ah ! It is the business of a worshipful officer to scorn deceit and to suffer .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: And all the people ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: The people are the people . But we soldiers are soldiers — and must drink , or we cannot guard .Yawns .Eh ! I could lie down and snore for seven years , but I am appointed to watch all night .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: suddenly caressingSweet warrior ! Would I could rest thee !

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: startled by the change in her demeanourHaggith ! Thou art marvellously and desirably changed .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: I am practising to thy profit for that which lies before me and my mistress .

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: What meanest thou ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: Chut ! If thou hast heard a word , let it die with thee — it will not burst thee .

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: Lord ! turn away from me vain hopes and concupiscence .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: And so thou sleepest not this night !... Neither do I sleep .

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: I go with my mistress upon a journey .

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: What journey ? There can be no journey for thee , unless thou leave the city and wend to the Assyrians .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: curt againNevertheless we go upon a journey .

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: It is madness .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: It may be .

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: Who can tell the heart of a master ? Not I ! When dost thou depart ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: My mistress is attiring .

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: Thou dost not attire her ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: I ! I , who have charge over all that is hers ! Wilt thou tell me , then , what is the task of her tiring-women ? Idle sluts !

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: And this is thy baggage ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: matter-of-factA cruse of oil , a bag of parched corn , fine bread , three lumps of figs — and a bottle of wine — yea , the last !

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: drawing in his lipsAh ! But thou wilt need an ass for this cargo .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: drilyI am the ass .

div.stage: Enter Judith , magnificently dressed .
The soldier retires , back .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Is all prepared ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: All is prepared , mistress .

div.stage: Enter Ozias , L .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: ecstatic at the sight of Judith 's splendourO , loveliness ! O , lily of the field ! Who shall withstand you , and who shall say you nay ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: smilingI am ready to depart .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: The secret way is opened . I will lead you to it .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: gentlyThe secret way ? I will take no secret way .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: But hear me , lady . The peril from the archers far off —

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: What did I say to you , lord Ozias ? I said : You shall stand this night in the gate of the city , and I will go forth . My desire is that you command the gatemen to open the gates , so that I and my waiting-woman may pass out before all men , and in the sight of the Lord .She bends to examine Haggith 's baggage .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: moved . Calling to the soldiersHo ! Let the gates of the city be opened , that the lady Judith may go forth .

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: Yea , lord .Calling to others , off .Gatemen !

div.stage: The gatemen man the gate-chains , and citizens rush in with cries : ‘ What shall happen to us ? The lady Judith leaves the city ? At night-fall ? What is it ? ’

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: fiercely , to the crowdGet hence ! Dogs !

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: softlyLet them stay , Lord Ozias , for that which I do , I do not in secret , neither shall it be hidden .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: to the crowdMake a way clear to the gates .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Before I go , I will look into the valley whither I descend .She mounts to the vantage-point

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: Water ! Water ! Or we die !

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: from the vantage-pointBrethren , bewail not ! Remember what things the Lord did to Abraham , and how he tried Isaac , and what happened to Jacob in Mesopotamia . For the Lord has not tried us in the fire as he did them , neither has he taken vengeance upon us . But the Lord scourges them that come near to him , to admonish them .She kneels . Following her example , everybody kneels .O Lord God of my father Simeon , the Assyrians are multiplied in their power ; they trust in shield , and spear , and bow , and sling ; and know not that thou art the Lord which breakest battles ; the Lord is thy name . Behold their pride , and send thy wrath upon their heads ; give into my hand , which am a widow , the power that I have conceived . For thy power standeth not in multitude , nor thy might in strong men . Smite the Assyrians by the deceit of my lips ; break down their stateliness by the hand of a woman . And make my speech and deceit to be their wound and stripe , who have purposed cruel things against thy covenant and against the top of Zion . And make every nation and tribe to acknowledge that thou art the God of all power , and that there is none other that protecteth the people of Israel but thou .She rises . The crowd murmurs : ‘ Amen . ’ All rise . Judith comes down from the vantage-point . Silence .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: movedOpen the gates .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: to HaggithNothing is forgotten ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: Nothing .

div.stage: Judith moves a step towards the gates .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: The soul of my soul goes with you into the valley .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: to Haggith , solemnlyAnd the knife ?

div.stage: Haggith gives a gesture . At the same moment a woman comes from the house with a knife , which she hands to Haggith , who hands it to Judith , who takes it ceremoniously , and hides it in her dress . The gates are now opened , and the distant plain under the setting sun is seen covered with the tents of the Assyrian army .
Judith goes slowly through the gates , followed by Haggith carrying the baggage .

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: as Judith passesWater ! Water !

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: with deep emotionClose the gates . Light the watchfires .

div.stage: The gates begin slowly to close . The glow of the watchfires is seen .
CURTAIN .

div.head: SCENE I

stage.stage: The valley of Jezreel . The city of Bethulia on the hill in the distance .
Haggith with her baggage enters to Ingur and his men .

sp.speaker: TIME
sp.p: The next morning but one .

sp.speaker: INGUR
sp.p: What art thou ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: prudishly and coldlyIf it please thee , I am a woman .

sp.speaker: INGUR
sp.p: No . Thou art a hedgehog .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: suddenly cajolingI ask pardon . When I saw thy great handsomeness I grew afraid , and my tongue was stiffened . In my country there is no man so handsome as thou art .

sp.speaker: INGUR
sp.p: Ah !Much mollified .And what then is thy country ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: I am a woman of the Hebrews , and I have come from Bethulia .

sp.speaker: INGUR
sp.p: astonishedA woman of the Hebrews ! From Bethulia !To his menStand back from my face .The men retire . To Haggith .This is a rare strange tale .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: Could I lie to thee ? I have escaped from the city , which is given over to be consumed . I sought water for my thirst , for in Bethulia there is no water , and the people faint in the streets .

sp.speaker: INGUR
sp.p: But it is a long journey from Bethulia , and thou art fresh and delicate as though just risen from thy bed .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: smilingI can hide nothing from thee , mighty wolf . I am , indeed , but just risen from my bed . The night before last night I set forth secretly , and came into the valley yesterday at noon , and lay soft in a cave where three springs bubbled , and drank , and slept until this morning 's sunrise .

sp.speaker: INGUR
sp.p: What is thy name ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: Haggith .

sp.speaker: INGUR
sp.p: Thy name is as strange as thy errand , and as thyself ; and surely thou art a woman of the Hebrews , which is a race of lunatics , as I am told .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: I have figs fit for a great king .Opens her sack and offers some figs .

sp.speaker: INGUR
sp.p: eatingUm ! And what else hast thou ? Let me touch thee , Haggith .He touches her carefullyYes , thou art outlandish , and no doubt mad , but comely . Comely ! Thou hast the likeness and feel of a woman . Always have I hankered after strange women , and now lo ! one falls ripe into my mouth .Haggith shrinks . Reassuringly .In a way of speaking ! In a way speaking ! For thou art not in my mouth . And so thou earnest to slake thy thirst ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: Yes , my roaring lion .

sp.speaker: INGUR
sp.p: Listen ! Thou hast saved thy life with water . But thou art lost .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: Lost ?

sp.speaker: INGUR
sp.p: Ay ! A woman in the camps of the Assyrians — she is undone . She is a lamb in a den of terrible tigers .Comfortingly .No , no ! I will protect thee , but I warn thee that thou art undone . I am honest .Caresses her .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: clumsily returning his caressThou wilt not harm me .

sp.speaker: INGUR
sp.p: I will not tear thee to pieces , but thou shalt come away with me .She timidly strokes himThou hast not the habit of this stroking .

lg.l: My mistress commanded me , when I encountered any noble
Assyrian , to use him thus . It is true that I have not the habit .
Nevertheless I do what I can .

sp.speaker: INGUR
sp.p: startled at the mention of a mistressThy — thy mistress ? Ye are two ? Where then is thy mistress ? Tell me upon the instant — is she fairer than thou ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: Seven times more fair .

sp.speaker: INGUR
sp.p: Fetch her !

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: My mistress is washing herself in a fountain of water by the cave . She sent me forward in peace and friendliness to announce her coming .

sp.speaker: INGUR
sp.p: Fetch her !Suddenly perceiving Bagoas in the distance , he changes his manner .Stay ! Bagoas is approaching , and he may have seen thee . His eyes are sharp . Stand off .Haggith moves away a little .But when I tell thee , fall down on thy face .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: Is he a great captain ?

sp.speaker: INGUR
sp.p: His mightiness is the chief eunuch of the Prince , and there is none greater than he save only the Prince himself , for Bagoas has charge over all the women of the Prince 's tents .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: Women of the Prince 's tents ?

sp.speaker: INGUR
sp.p: Ay ! Wives ! Concubines ! Virgins ! Beyond counting . Didst thou think in thy Hebrew pride , that the Prince was a savage and a barbarian ?... Down , damsel ! Here is Bagoas . Embrace the earth for thy life 's sake .Haggith obeys .

div.stage: Enter Bagoas , with attendants , L .
Ingur salutes him with extreme deference .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Who art thou ?

sp.speaker: INGUR
sp.p: Ingur , mightiness , commanding twenty footmen .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Begone from my sight . This morning the Prince condescends to walk through the camp , that all the armies may take joy in his countenance . It is not meet that he should be seen of any lower than a lieutenant .

sp.speaker: INGUR
sp.p: indicating HaggithMightiness , a woman of the Hebrews escaped from Bethulia to find water ! And by my subtlety I have captured her .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: A woman of the Hebrews !Surveying Haggith .Rise , scum , and let me behold thy deformity .Haggith obeys .

sp.speaker: INGUR
sp.p: And there is another yet to appear ,— her mistress , seven times fairer .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Her mistress may be seven times fairer than this eyesore , and yet ugly .To Haggith .Who is thy mistress ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: The lady Judith .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Judith ! A name fit only for a cat ! Why is she here ? How is she here ? What is her secret and detestable purpose ? For there is a trick in this thing .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: I know not my mistress 's purpose .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Tell me thy mistress 's purpose , or I will have thee smothered .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: I know only that if Holofernes ——

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: stopping her angrilyCallest thou the illustrious one by his name ? The most high Prince Holofernes , foul wench .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: The most high Prince Holofernes — if he so wills my mistress would speak with his highness .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: laughing heartilySpeak with the Prince ? Speak with the Prince ? Ha-ha !All the men laugh .What is the state of thy mistress ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: The lady Judith is a widow .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: still more amusedAha ! A widow ! And the Hebrew hag would speak with Prince Holofernes !The men laugh and jeer .

div.stage: Enter Judith , R .
Haggith goes quickly to her . All the men stare at Judith , deeply impressed .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: aside to JudithThere are many hussies in the camps , thousands and thousands , mistress . This lord is the chief eunuch .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: aside to an attendantIf this be an example of the Bethulian women , I shall have a momentous business upon me when their city falls .

sp.speaker: FIRST ATTENDANT
sp.p: Yea , mightiness .

div.stage: Judith , signing to Haggith to stand aside , bows to the ground before Bagoas ; then rises again .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: after a short pauseYou are very beautiful .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: There are beautiful women in Judea , but no man of Judea would look twice at such as I , a shrunken widow , like dried fish .

div.stage: Exit Ingur , excitedly , L .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: I have heard how you have escaped out of Bethulia and come hither in order to find water .Blandly .Aught else ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: My desire also was to have speech privately with the great conqueror , Holofernes .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Ah ! We are well met , you and I . For I am Bagoas , chief eunuch to the illustrious Prince .Aside to second attendant .Run . Fetch the box of veils .Exit second attendant , L .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: saluting once moreI supplicate then , mighty Bagoas , that you lead me quickly to the illustrious Prince Holofernes .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Surely ! Surely ! It is my pleasure to content you .Aside , to attendant , anxiously .This dried fish by her damnable beauty will reach great power , and if I speak not softly to her now she will undo me in that day .

sp.speaker: FIRST ATTENDANT
sp.p: Yea , mightiness .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: I humbly thank your mightiness .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: But it is necessary that you should relate to me your little affair . For no woman speaks to the illustrious Prince until she has spoken to me .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: It cannot be so .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: persuasivelyIn my ear , privily . Approach .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: It cannot be so .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: What mean you — it cannot be so ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: I will utter my errand to the illustrious Prince Holofernes alone .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: losing his self-control ; angrilyWhat ? Thou queasy chit ! Thou minx ! Thou jade ! Baggage ! Mopsy ! Shamelesss wench ! Thou wilt not obey Bagoas , chief eunuch in the camps of the Assyrians ! I will make thee the slave of my slave and the plaything of scullions .Stops . Judith smiles . Haggith subsides alarmed at her feet .Thou shalt be abandoned to the sutlers and the ass-drivers , and thus thou shalt learn who is Bagoas and what is his power !Stops again . Judith still smiles .The strumpets of the kitchens shall scorn thee ! I — I ——

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: smiling sweetlyMightiness ! Mightiness ! I am your bondwoman , but it is appointed by heaven that I shall speak with the illustrious Prince Holofernes himself .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: controlling himself , smilingWell , if it is appointed by heaven , so shall it be . Forget my words . They had no evil intent , for I was trying you , as my duty is .Aside to attendant .The sweetness of her glance dissolves my backbone .

sp.speaker: FIRST ATTENDANT
sp.p: Yea , mightinesss .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: to JudithFollow me , lady .Aside to attendant .Thinkest thou the Prince will come this way ?Pointing .

sp.speaker: FIRST ATTENDANT
sp.p: Yea , mightiness .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Or that ?

sp.speaker: FIRST ATTENDANT
sp.p: Yea , mightiness .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: If the Prince so much as sees her before the city is taken , never will the city be taken , and we shall all be her captives .

sp.speaker: FIRST ATTENDANT
sp.p: Yea , mightiness .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: beating the attendantI will lead her by the path to the cave , for the Prince will surely not come that way .To Judith .Follow me , lady .

div.stage: Bagoas moves R. Judith hesitates a moment as Haggith picks up her sack . Enter R. the heralds of Holofernes , followed by Holofernes .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: to himselfHolofernes !To his attendants .Hide her , rascals , or Assyria is undone .The attendants range themselves between Judith and Holofernes .

div.stage: Bagoas receives Holofernes with a prostration and high ceremony .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Where is this woman ?

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Woman , Prince ?

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: impatientThis Hebrew woman , I say ! One Ingur has run among the tents chattering , and the rumour of her has spread through the camps like a plague . By Nebuchadnezzar the one god , where is she , for it has been told to me that her beauty excels the beauty of all the women of the East and ravishes the eye exceedingly ?

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Ah ! It is of Judith that the Prince deigns to speak . Lo ! I had caught her and was bringing her to your highness .To attendants .Stand aside , dogs .

div.stage: Judith is revealed to Holofernes . She prostrates herself and then rises . Holofernes gazes at her , entranced .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: So thou hast escaped out of Bethulia to find water for thy thirst ?

lg.l: To find water , and to have speech with the most illustrious

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Womanapproaching her a step , and then standing still, be of good comfort , and fear not in thy heart , for I never hurt any that was willing to serve Nebuchadnezzar , the god of all the earth . And if thy people that dwell in the mountains had not held me lightly , I would not have lifted up my spear against them , but they have done these things to themselves .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: aside , to HolofernesTerrible master , she is full of guile and deceitfulness , and came not at all for water , but for a hidden purpose against you . Therefore enquire of her closely .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: to BagoasChastise thy tongue , ere it overthrow thee , fiend . There is no guile in that face .To Judith .Tell me now thy message and wherefore in truth thou art come . And tremble not , for thou shalt live this night .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Great prince , receive the words of your servant and suffer your handmaid to speak in your presence , and I will declare no lie to my lord .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Speak .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: I will speak to my lord alone .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: aside to HolofernesIt is a device against my lord .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: to JudithSpeak now , I command thee .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: My message concerns the fate of Bethulia , and of all the Assyrians , and of my lord . Life and death are in it , for I have communed with heaven .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Which heaven ? Thine or mine ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: There is but one God .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: roughlyAnd he is Nebuchadnezzar . Speak thy tale .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: I will speak to my lord alone .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: aside to HolofernesIt is a device .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: angrilySpeak out all thy heart , and quickly !

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: I will speak to my lord in my lord 's tent .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: furiousIn my tent ! Who art thou who defiest me , and what is thy licence , heathen slave , to defile the tent of Holofernes ? Bind her . Take her away , and twist the cords about her neck , and strangle her , and cast her insolence into the lake .

div.stage: Judith is seized and bound in an instant .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: in two mindsWait !

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: She is bound , illustrious prince .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Wait !

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: aside to HolofernesPrince , let not the benevolence of your heart be your undoing , for in the loveliness of her face is cunning and great peril . I have lived all my days amid the craftiness of women , and my lord also knows somewhat of their strange tricks , which bring ruin to the carnal .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: reflectiveWho would despise these Hebrews that have among them such women as she ?FiercelySurely it is not good that one man among them should be left ; for if one were let go he might deceive the whole earth .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: advancing a step , appealinglyWill the wise man cast away a pearl , and will my lord in anger lose his servant for ever ?

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: to HolofernesLet her not speak with my lord alone in my lord 's tent .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: I would speak with the illustrious prince — and with Bagoas also .She smiles .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: with a gestureI cannot lose thee .To attendants .Unbind her .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: asideMay heaven be with us , for the woman is against us !

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: to BagoasVeil her , that her face and form be not seen as she passes to my tent , for she is mine .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: callingThe veils ! The veils ! Where is the rascal ? The attendant rushes in panting with the box of veils . He is followed by Ingur .

div.stage: Judith is elaborately veiled in a series of veils by Bagoas and his attendants ) .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Let her follow me .

div.stage: Exeunt , R , with great ceremony , Holofernes and his heralds , followed by Judith .

sp.speaker: INGUR
sp.p: as they go , stopping Bagoas , who goes lastMightiness , pardon your slave .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: INGUR
sp.p: pointing to HaggithYour slave captured the mistress . Reward him with this outlandish wench .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: carelesslyThe fool goeth out to seek his own damnation . Take her .

div.stage: CURTAIN .

div.head: SCENE II

stage.stage: Interior of the tent of Holofernes . A couch with curtains , L. The principal entrance to the tent is at the back . Secondary entrances in the hangings , L. and R .

lg.l: Bagoas and his attendant are unveiling Judith .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Animal , wouldst thou dare to behold that which is thy lord 's ? Leave the last veil , and away with thee .

sp.speaker: FIRST ATTENDANT
sp.p: Yea , mightiness !

div.stage: Exit back with the veils already removed from Judith .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Queen of the night of Holofernes !

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: through the veilMighty Bagoas !

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: The Prince comes to look upon you in his tent .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Mighty Bagoas , deign to answer a question I will put .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Deign to ask , lady , and my humility shall answer ; for your beauty has blinded Holofernes this day and he is your captive , and his servant is your servant , and there is no law in the camps of the Assyrians save your glance .He makes a covert gesture of half-amused resentful resignation .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Nebuchadnezzar is your god ? Is it not so , Bagoas ?

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Nebuchadnezzar is henceforward the god of the Assyrians and of all the lands which their spears conquer . It is an official order .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: If Nebuchadnezzar laid a command upon you , would you disregard it ?

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: I would not , for my skin is very valuable to me .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: As Nebuchadnezzar is your god , so is the Lord of Israel mine . And my God laid a secret command upon me to speak with Prince Holofernes alone and with none other in his tent . Thus , and thus only , was it that I refused to speak in the presence even of the mighty Bagoas . But as I withstood you in the valley there , the God of Israel descended upon me and I heard the voice of God in my ear , and the voice said : ‘ It is permitted to thee to speak with Bagoas also . ’ Therefore I yielded to the importunity of Prince Holofernes and of Bagoas .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Your god is a wise god and has discernment .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: This I tell you , that there may be peace and good intelligence between us . Is there peace between us ?

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Lady , in my heat I admonished you with hard words and much vituperation .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: innocently .By Nebuchadnezzar , I heard none .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: There is peace between us . And in the closeness of our intelligence you and I will rule them that rule all Assyria .

div.stage: Enter Holofernes , L .
Bagoas prostrates himself . Holofernes walks about , ignoring Judith .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: to BagoasAt what hour is the Council of Captains ?

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: The Council awaits your highness .

div.stage: Suddenly Holofernes snatches the veil from Judith , and throws it on the floor . He gazes at her . Judith prostrates herself . Holofernes drops on to the couch , and looks at everything except Judith .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: imperiouslyRise .Judith rises . A pause . Holofernes plays with a jewel on his costume . Without looking at Judith .And Achior ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Illustrious Prince .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Did the slave reach Bethulia ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: The men of Bethulia took him , and he declared to them all that he had spoken to my lord Prince . And many approved him .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: And what sayest thou of Achior ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: O lord and governor , I say : Reject not the word of Achior , but lay it up in your heart .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Thou art bold .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: The word of Achior is true . For the Israelites shall not be punished , and the sword shall not prevail against them , except they sin against their God .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Not even my sword ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Not even the sword of my lord and governor , except they sin against their God .With significance .But they will sin .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Ah ! They will sin ? In what will they sin ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Death is fallen upon them , and they will provoke their God to anger , for their water is scant , and they faint in their thirst ; and they will drink the holy wine which was sanctified and reserved for the priests who serve before the face of our God : which thing is not lawful for any of the people so much as to touch with their hands .

lg.l: What has all this to do with me ? There is no god but

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: It touches my lord and governor , because , knowing all this , I am fled from Bethulia , which shall be accurst ; and the God of Israel has sent me to work things with my lord and governor whereat the whole earth shall be astonished .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: looking at her , interestedWhat things ? And what have I to do with thy god ? I need not thy god , for after the Israelites have drunk their wine they will thirst again ; and when the city is broken with fainting , it will fall safe into my hands while I sit and watch .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: with fireAnd when the city has fallen while the Assyrians sit and watch , and when all men whisper one to another that the greatest captain of the earth conquered by a device because he dared not attack boldly with spear , and bow , and sling — in that day will my lord and governor be content ? Or will he be ashamed , and blush to lift up his eyes ?

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: disturbedIt is a true word .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: It is a true word .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: savagelyThis day will I attack the city and take it , and though I make fifty thousand widows and orphans in Assyria I will compass Bethulia , and not one house in it shall be left standing , nor one Israelite alive .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: shaking her head slowlyWhy is my lord against the pleasure of the Most High ? Do I not say , and has it not been revealed to me , that Bethulia shall not perish until its inhabitants have sinned before God ? Listen , illustrious Prince , I will remain this night . And when the time comes I will go into the valley , and I will pray to God , and mayhap He will tell me when the Israelites in Bethulia have committed their sin . And I will come and show it to you , and thereupon my lord and governor shall go forth with all his army , and none shall resist him .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: fascinatedThou wilt come to me when the time is at hand for my triumph !

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: And hearken further ! I will lead my lord and governor in the midst of Judea , until he comes to Jerusalem ; and I will set his throne in the midst of Jerusalem , and a dog shall not so much as open his mouth at my lord and prince . For these things were declared unto me from on high , and I am sent to tell them .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: aside to Bagoas , excitedlyThere is not such a woman from one end of the earth to the other , both for beauty of face and wisdom of words .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: It may well be so , Prince . But I have not seen the whole earth .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: to JudithThou hast done well to come to me , that strength may be in my hands and destruction upon them that lightly regard Nebuchadnezzar , the one god . Thou art ravishing in countenance , and if thou do as thou hast spoken , thou shalt dwell in my house which is over against the house of King Nebuchadnezzar , and thou shalt be renowned through the east and through the west . Bagoas , prepare meat and wine for her .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: making as if to give an orderTo hear is to obey .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: I will not eat of my lord 's meat , nor drink of his wine , lest there be offence ; I have brought provision by my waiting-woman .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: But if thy provision fail ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: significantlyMy provision will not fail before the Lord works by my hand the things which He has determined . Bagoas claps his hands . Enter an attendant .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Fetch Haggith , the waiting-woman of the lady Judith ! Quickly !Exit attendant . To Holofernes .Prince , shall the Hebrew woman eat and drink of her provision in my lord 's tent ?

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: She shall eat and drink in my tent , and she shall not leave it .

lg.l: Then it is right that my lord remains not . And moreover the
Council humbly waits for my lord .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: to Judith , as he follows HolofernesDid I not say that you and I shall rule them that rule Assyria ?Exit L .

div.stage: Enter Haggith , back , with provisions .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: excited , looking round to see if they are aloneMistress ! Is it possible ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: What has taken thee ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: Is this the tent of the monster ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Hush !

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: whisperingIt is greater and more magnificent than the temple at Bethulia .Looking into a corner .But unclean . Have they no besoms ?... Ah !Looking up at the roof .The bigness of it makes me small like a child before it can walk . I could not live comfortably in such a great windy place . No ! I prefer our own house to all this royalty .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Give me food , Haggith . Where hast thou been ?She sits .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: Mistress , I have been with the man Ingur !Arranging Judith 's costume , and then setting out the food and wine .In obedience to your command . At Bethulia , being busied all my days with the ordering of your possessions , I had no time for traffic with men ; neither desire . And I deemed them terrible and masterful creatures . And when you commanded me to go forth into the camps and delude and entangle with wiles whatever Assyrian I should meet , I was afraid . For it was in my heart that I could not accomplish this thing . Yet I have done it prettily . And it is easier to me far than sweeping with a besom . Either all men are simpletons and besotted with self-conceit , or Ingur exceeds greatly in folly . I have been given to him for his slave , but he is mine and knows it not .She sits .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Where hast thou left him ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: Mistress I would not suffer that you should pass from my sight , and I followed you , and Ingur followed me gladly , and at last the guard seized him for that he was found within the precincts of the prince 's quarter , which is forbidden to his rank , and many stripes will be his . Mistress , you eat not .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: trying to eatYes , I eat . Do thou eat for me .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: I have eaten and drunk — with Ingur .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: But not of his provision ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: noddingHe so softly entreated me .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: It is a sin and an offence for thee , being an Israelite .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: For such as my high-born mistress , it is an offence . But for the handmaid — pooh ! She eats as she can , and the Lord turneth away his glance until she has finished her platter . Moreover , did you not lay it upon me to beguile the dolt ? And verily , mistress , I have rejoiced much this day ; and Ingur ——

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Silence with thy prattle . Bethink thee of the dread business upon which I am come down from Bethulia into the valley ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: subdued ; offering foodEat , mistress .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: I cannot . My soul rejects it , and my body is on fire with expectation and suspense .Rising . Haggith also rises .Stay thou where thou art , for I will go forth alone . I must commune with the God of Israel for my tranquillity , and I dare not seek him in the tent of the heathen .Exit , back .

div.stage: Haggith gathers the meat together .
Enter Holofernes and Bagoas , L .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: looking about the tent , alarmedWhere is she ? Has she fled ? If she has escaped me , this shall be thy last day , Bagoas . What is this girl here ?

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Prince , has any woman yet slipped through these hands ? This girl is the waiting wench of the lady Judith .To Haggith .Where is thy mistress , wench ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: frightened and foolishMy mistress having eaten ... having eaten naught , is gone to — to — to — pray .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Bring her . Her god may wait , but not the illustrious Prince . Run with both thy legs .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: Ye — es , mightiness .Exit , back

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Bagoas , with thine arts thou shalt persuade the Hebrew woman to come to us and to eat and drink with us this night .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: grimlyPersuasion shall be used , highness . My arts are many and various .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: It will be a shame for our person if we let such a woman go , not having delighted in her company . If we do not draw her to us she will laugh us to scorn .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Yea , highness . But my lord has but this moment appointed a great feast with his captains at sunset . How then shall he eat and drink with the lady Judith ?

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Thick-skull ! Speak not to me of my captains ! The Council of the Captains was as dust in my mouth , and I could not away with it . Therefore I sharply dismissed the Council , and soothed their damnable pride with the promise of a mighty feast . But what care I for the captains ? My heart thirsts horribly for this Hebrew woman , and I am full of a great madness .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: So be it , highness . Nevertheless , the Prince has promised to his captains a mighty feast , and the word of Holofernes is a rock that cannot be shaken .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Oh ! What a calamity is love ! And there is no slave so trodden down as him that is the slave of desire .... Bah ! I will eat and drink quickly with the captains , and the woman shall await me here .

div.stage: Enter Judith , back . On seeing Holofernes she prostrates herself .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Arise , sorceress .Judith rises . To Bagoas .Go fetch leopard skins for her repose .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: I will send for the skins on the instant , highness .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Thou wilt go thyself to fetch them , elephant . And come not back without the finest skins in my wardrobe . See to it .

div.stage: Exit Bagoas , back .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Come closer .Judith obeys .Look into my eyes .Judith obeys .Sorceress , thou knowest thy power .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: I have no power , save that which is given to me from on high .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Thou wast praying to thy god ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Yea , highness .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Didst thou demand of him that he should tell thee if the Israelites in Bethulia had committed their sin , and if the time of my triumph was at hand ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: No , lord . I prayed for the forgiveness of the transgressions of thy handmaid .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Why didst thou not demand of him what I ask thee ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Who am I to hasten the God of Israel ? In the night time , and in the darkness , when all men sleep ,— then it is that my God condescends towards me , and my ear hears his secret purposes .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: lowThis night ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Who can search out heaven ?

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: This night ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: It may be .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: And thou wilt come to me in the night and tell me thy message ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: I will come to thee in the night , great prince .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: And thou wilt eat and drink with me in my triumph ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: after a pauseIf it pleases my lord .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Thou wilt eat of my meat and drink of my wine , which I will give thee ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: after a pauseIf my lord is alone and there is none with him . For it is not right that any should see me .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: I will be alone . But Bagoas shall stand at the door of the tent .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: As my lord wills .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: ecstatic , moving a little towards her ; she respondsFairest among women ! Can it be !... The way of God is wondrous .

div.stage: A half-veiled Assyrian woman appears through the hangings R ., and watches .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: solemnly and significantlyThere are yet hid greater things than this , and thou hast yet seen but a few of his works .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: sinking back on the couch , mysteriously afraidSorceress !

div.stage: The watcher disappears .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: cooinglyDoes my lord shrink from his handmaid ?

div.stage: Holofernes stretches his hands to her .
CURTAIN .

div.head: SCENE III

sp.speaker: TIME
sp.p: The same night . Wine and food are set by the couch . A lamp is burning .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: at back entrance to tent , calling to people offTo your beds , all of you . Let none remain .He stands a moment at the entrance ; a few distant shouts are heard ; then silence . Bagoas comes within the tent towards the couch . To Holofernes .The waiters are gone , Prince . There is no one left to disturb the night .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Hast thou seen her ?

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: after a pauseNo , prince .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: But didst thou look ?

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: I looked , O illustrious .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Is there moonlight ?

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: The moon is clouded , highness .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Give me wine .Bagoas obeys .Bagoas !

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Prince ?

div.stage: The hangings of the tent R ., balloon inwards a little .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: looking behind him sharply , spilling some wineThe wind is rising .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: It is but a night breeze .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: as he drinks gloomilyBagoas , she has escaped back to her own people .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
