sp.p: asideI would she had , the jade !To Holofernes .Prince , she cannot escape . Every path from the valley is guarded .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: What guard could restrain such a woman ?

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: Ah ! Prince ! What guard could restrain her ?

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Dost thou echo me ?

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: I humbly think the thought of his highness .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Do thy thinking outside .

div.stage: Bagoas bows and moves towards the entrance . Judith is standing there . The two look at each other for a moment .

sp.speaker: BAGOAS
sp.p: with a gesture , indicating JudithHighness !

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Jumping up . To BagoasBegone to thy post !

div.stage: Judith glides in silently . Bagoas goes out . They pass by each other without a word or a salutation , but mutually scrutinizing .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: The great feast of the captains is over ?

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: The captains are departed , drunken with wine and their pride . But thy feast and my feast is not begun .Points to the repast .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: enigmatically .I am here .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: ecstatic .Art thou in truth here , or do my eyes behold that which is not ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Did I not say that I should come in the night ?

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Yea , I trusted thee . I trusted thee so much that at the feast of the captains I commanded that all my hosts shall attack Bethulia , with bow , and sling , and spear , at sunrise , and also I gave the word of Holofernes for a pledge that naught in the heavens or on the earth should resist the onset of the Assyrians ; for some among them feared the word of Achior which they had heard .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: You have not done this thing ?

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: I have done it .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Would you forestall God , and would you speak the decrees of God before they are uttered ?

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Thou saidst thou wouldst pray to thy god this night and that he would tell thee when the Israelites in Bethulia had committed their sin , and that thou wouldst come to me to proclaim the hour of my triumph .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: I said : I will pray to God and mayhap he will tell me .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Thou hast prayed , and thy god hath not answered ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: He has not answered .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: with bravadoHe is no god , then , thy god . Let us drink .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: as Holofernes moves towards her , solemnlyTouch not your handmaid , and touch not the goblet .She goes to the skins , R .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: following Judith gentlyThou art offended .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Stand afar off , Holofernes , and meddle not with her that communes with the Most High .

div.stage: Judith kneels . Holofernes goes in the direction of the couch . Silence . Bagoas has been seen once or twice in the porch of the tent , his back turned . He has now gone again . Two half-veiled Assyrian women appear through the hangings , R ., and watch a moment , then vanish . Judith slowly rises .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: What has befallen thee ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: It has befallen me that this moment the God of Israel has spoken and my ear has heard his command .Approaching Holofernes .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: What saith thy god ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: My ear has heard that the Israelites in Bethulia have committed their sin , and at sunrise the Assyrians shall assault Bethulia and none shall withstand them .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: A miracle !

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: A miracle in thy tent , O great warrior !

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: To-morrow is appointed to be the day of my triumph .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: movedYea , it is so .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: gratefullyHear me , Judith . Thy god shall be my god .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: In truth thou art set apart to be his . HOLOFERNESclose to herThy body trembles .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: smilingThinkst thou then that I was not afraid for thee ? But my fear is gone from me , for now I know thy fate and the decree of heaven concerning thee .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: asideTo-morrow is appointed for my triumph , but this night also shall I exult .To Judith .Let us eat and drink together , for we are alone in the night , and thou hast promised .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: gailyLet us feast .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: animated by her responsive toneTake off thy tunic ; thou art in thy own house . Let Holofernes be thy tire-woman .Approaching her .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: No !Moving from him to the further side of the couch .But he shall be my slave to serve me . Pour out the wine , great slave .

div.stage: While Holofernes cheerfully obeys , Judith takes the knife from her garments and places it behind the couch . Then , as he stands with the wine , gazing at her and separated from her only by the couch , she slowly removes her tunic and appears in indoor attire . She comes towards him and takes the wine from him and drinks .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: I feared that in the strictness of thy Hebrew scruples thou wouldst not drink of my wine .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: I will drink again .She does so .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: taking the goblet and drinkingDost thou verily know thy power and thy dominion , Judith ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: simplyYes , I know it now better than thou .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Thou dost not . For I am mad for thee , and thou hast set thy seal upon me for evermore . My heart cannot hold thee , for thou hast filled it to overflowing , and all men see that my heart is full of thee and runneth over . Yea , I have a hundred and two and thirty thousand that bow themselves at my feet and that live and die by my glance . And I am at thy feet and thy glance is my joy and my sorrow according to thy whim . Judith , I entreat thee , command me something . For whatever thou command me , that will I execute . And be not afraid in thy command , for my power is very great and there is none like it save only my lord Nebuchadnezzar 's .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: tenderlyI command thee that thou be happy . For thy captive has no other desire .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Say not my captive . For it is I that am thy prisoner . And I will set thee on my throne , and in my great boldness I will dare to sit beside thee . But thou shalt reign . And we will live together in Assyria long years .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: changing her moodThere is no requisition in the grave whether you have lived ten or an hundred or a thousand years . But the God of Israel is a shield .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: eagerlyAnd I have told thee that thy god shall be my god ; but in secret , because of that which I owe to King Nebuchadnezzar . Yet shall the whole earth know that thou , Judith , alone art my god .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: But thou hast other wives .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: No !

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Yes ! It has been whispered to me that thou hast many wives , and concubines without number .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: It is a lie . For from this night I have put away from me all women but thee , and there is not one among them to compare with thee .AppealinglyAnd since the judgment of heaven hath done a miracle by thee in the tent of Holofernes this night , wilt thou deny , O tenderness ! that thou hast been divinely appointed to me , and I to thee ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: I will not deny that the Lord is in this thing . And for thy comfort I will tell thee that which thou knowest not .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: expectantTell me .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Before I escaped from Bethulia , as I lay on my bed , a vision came to me , and it was the vision of Holofernes in the likeness of his majesty and his might . And I saw the vision by my bed , and so it was that I came down into the valley ....Softly .And wouldst thou that I should have uttered this secret to any but thee !

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: full of emotionI will kiss thy lips , and thou art mine , O fragrance !

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Kiss my lips .

div.stage: Holofernes kisses her , and then in an excess of feeling stumbles backward .

A half-veiled Assyrian woman appears at the opening R ., and watches . Bagoas , in the porch of the tent , turns and sees her , and dashes at her with a weapon . Both disappear through the opening , R .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: moving with stealth towards the hidden knife , comfortinglyO mighty child , where is thy strength , and where is thy terribleness ? Rest thee a moment on the couch , and thy soul 's captive will tend thee .

div.stage: Holofernes drops on the couch , and Judith caresses him .

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: murmuringMy great joy has overthrown me .

div.stage: Judith , seizing the knife and leaning over Holofernes , kills him while she is still caressing .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: as she uses the knife ; murmuringThou that wouldst go against the pleasure of the Most High ! Thou that wouldst defile Judea ! Thou that hast dishonoured with thy kiss the widow of Manasses ! Thou that hast compelled me to guile and deceit and much lying so that I might perform the will of God ! The grave shall be thy house !

div.stage: Enter Haggith , L .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: turning to Haggith , firmly and impressivelyI have done that which I had to do , and the power of Assyria is fallen .Pointing .Take the head by the beard , and put it in thy sack , and let us depart .

div.stage: CURTAIN .

div.head: SCENE I

sp.speaker: TIME
sp.p: A few hours later than Act II , Scene III , the same night . The sole light is that of torches , and watchfiresoffThe gatemen are at the gates . There is a knocking on the outside of the gates .

div.stage: Enter First Soldier , running .

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: to a gateman , who is climbing up in order to look over the top of the gatesLook not over , booby . Thy fool 's face might meet the point of an Assyrian spear .The gateman slips down quickly .

div.stage: Renewed knocking .

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: shoutingNone can enter the city till sunrise . And not then if I like not the aspect of his phiz .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: offIt is Haggith , servant of the lady Judith . Open the gates quickly , for I am become a woman of much consequence .

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: Haggith ? It is the voice of Haggith ; yet it may also be devils .To another soldier who has entered .Run ! Rouse the lord Ozias .Exit soldier .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: I have water with me . Many gourds ! Fresh water ! Cool water !

div.stage: The gatemen begin to work the gate-chains .

lg.l: What do ye , dogs ? Stop , and await the order of the lord

sp.speaker: GATEMEN
sp.p: continuing to work the chainsWater ! Water !

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: Pull , then , dogs . If there is water and it is wet I will taste it . But if there is not water , I will slay the first soul that enters .As the gates begin to open a little .Hold ! No wider !

div.stage: Enter Haggith with two gourds .
The gourds are snatched from her , and the men , including the First Soldier , drink .

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: as he drinksYea , it is indeed Haggith . Where is thy mistress , and whence comest thou , my beloved water-carrier , for thou art my beloved ?Haggith slaps his face .

div.stage: Enter Ozias , L .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: furiousWhy are the gates opened ? What is this ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: Haggith , lord , with water that is stronger than wine .Handing a gourd to Ozias to soothe him .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Where is thy mistress , wench ?Drinks .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: stifflyI am the forerunner of my mistress , who has sent me , and before many hours are passed the lady Judith will come also .She goes to the gates and beckons .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: What art thou doing ?

div.stage: Enter Ingur , bearing a sack .

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: An Assyrian ! An Assyrian !Men spring at Ingur .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: Let him alone ; he is my bondman and I have tamed him .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Shut the gates , for I will enquire into this matter .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: There are yet ten other Assyrians outside the gates , carrying gourds for me .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Ten other Assyrians ! It is a trick !

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: proudlyBy my command they are chained by their necks , neck to neck . Fetch in the gourds , men , and give the people to drink .

div.stage: The gourds are brought in amid cries and excitement . They are taken off , L .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Shut the gates , I say .

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: And the ten Assyrians , great lord ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Let them await my enquiry where they stand .

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: Lord Ozias , if they flee ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: Hold thy mouth , gaby ! Wouldst thou flee with thy neck chained to nine necks ? Moreover , where will they flee ? For the camps of the Assyrians are broken , and in their terrible confusion the Assyrians fall one upon another .

div.stage: The gatemen talk among themselves and stare at the Assyrians outside , who cannot be seen by those within the city . The gates remain open a little .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: impatientlyWhat is thy tale , Haggith ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: My mistress has slain Holofernes in his tent in the night , and the power of Assyria is undone .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: astoundedSlain Holofernes ! Thou art mad in thy raving .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: to IngurOpen the mouth of the sack , and let my lord behold the head of Holofernes and see that I am mad .To soldier .A torch , that the Lord Ozias may discover the manner of my raving .

div.stage: Ozias looks into the sack and sees the head of Holofernes .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Great is the Lord of Israel !

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: And my mistress is the right hand of the Lord .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Great is the Lord of Israel !

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: deeply movedHis name shall live for ever .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: How did thy mistress accomplish this mighty deed ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: AS for that , she will tell it to my lord with her own voice when she shall come . And now will my lord give ear to the commands of the lady Judith , which she doth lay upon my lord by me , Haggith ? First , the head of Holofernes shall be set upon a spear on the highest wall in the great square before the temple . So shall all the Israelites know that God yet watcheth over Israel .To the soldiers .Take the sack and do as my lady hath ordained by me , Haggith .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: to men , who hesitateTake the sack . It is my command .

div.stage: Exeunt two men , L ., with sack .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: Next , ye shall send men for water to the wells beneath the city that all may drink , for already the Assyrians are fled from the wells , knowing that Holofernes is dead . And ye shall send forth all your army into the valley to fall upon the Assyrians , for they are afraid of the judgment of God , and none dare abide in the sight of his neighbour . Neither can they stand against the chosen race of God .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: to First SoldierLet every armed man in the city be roused , and publish the order of Ozias that the Captains lead their bands swiftly into the valley by the secret way to fall upon the Assyrians .

div.stage: Exit First Soldier and another , with joyous cries , L .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: Thus hath the lady Judith spoken by me , Haggith .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Whither is thy mistress gone , and why does she tarry ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: My mistress is hidden in a sure place in the valley , for there is one among the Assyrians who fears not God . And he is Bagoas , the chief eunuch of Holofernes , and he has sworn an oath to kill my mistress , for that by guile she did cut off the head of Holofernes . And Bagoas searches for my mistress in the folds of the valley . But he will not find her .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: perturbedHow knowst thou that he will not find her ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: Because the Lord of Israel is a sharp sword and protecteth his servants .... And also because my mistress is most cunningly hidden .

div.stage: Enter Charmis , L .

sp.speaker: CHARMIS
sp.p: joyously excitedWhat is the miracle that I hear , Ozias ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: blandlyThere is no miracle ; but that which I had planned with the lady Judith has come to pass . Take women and old men Charmis , and go ye to the wells and bring water to the city , for the wells are delivered into my hands .

sp.speaker: CHARMIS
sp.p: hesitatingWomen and old men ? But the onslaught against the Assyrians of which I hear ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: imperiouslyGo quickly . For who is the governor of this city ? Is it thou or is it I ?

div.stage: Exit Charmis , L .
Men and women have gathered joyously in the street .

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: mockingly , indicating Ingur , with a tendency to horseplayThe Assyrian ! The Assyrian !

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Take him to the guard-house and chain him to Achior .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: He shall not go , lord Ozias . For as my mistress beguiled Holofernes , so did I beguile Ingur , and he is my slave . But I have not cut off his head , and he is dear to me because I have not cut off his head . And he is mine , and let none touch himlooking at the soldiers, or my anger , which is the anger of the lady Judith , shall be upon that man .Hearing a noise , she glances at the house .What do I see ? The sluts are in the tent of my mistress , which is forbidden them . Out , sluts !Exit angrily into the house !

div.stage: Ingur follows her quickly for protection .
Enter Messenger .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: And you ?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.p: salutingDo my eyes behold the great lord Ozias , governor of Bethulia ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Your eyes behold him .

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.p: It is not yet dawn , nevertheless the streets of the city are full of a great going and coming , but I found none to lead me to the house of the lord Ozias . Yet when I saw my lord 's visage my heart said : ‘ This is he . ’

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: What is your affair with me ?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.p: I am a messenger .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: curtlySpeak quickly , for the government of this city in this hour is no common matter , and the whole charge of it lies upon me .

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.p: And I am no common messenger . I come with wings through the night from Jerusalem , from Joachim , the high priest .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Ah !Changing his tone and beckoning the messenger aside .What tidings do you bear ?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.p: I bear the licence from Joachim .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: What licence ?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.p: The licence for the people of Bethulia to drink the wine which is sanctified and reserved to the priests which serve the Lord .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: affecting to be puzzledWho hath demanded this licence from Joachim ?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.p: surprisedThe lord Ozias sent a messenger to Jerusalem to beseech that the licence should be granted . And my lord 's messenger travelled so swiftly that in the moment when he reached the temple at Jerusalem he fell sick and vomited , and I have come to Bethulia in his place , for after he had vomited he unfolded to me the secret way into the city .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: grandlyIt is true . In the heavy multitude of my cares I had forgotten this matter of the licence .

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.p: confidentiallyAnd Joachim hath bidden me to say privily that if any have already in their extremity drunk of the sanctified wine it shall be denied utterly — for the sake of the church .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Ah !

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.p: And here is the licence .Offering it .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Friend , keep the licence and render it back to Joachim , the high priest in Jerusalem . For I need it not , and I demanded it only by excess of prudence such as becomes the governor of a city besieged and thirsting . But we Bethulians are a faithful and a constant people , and we have trusted in the Most High . And if perchance any have drunk of the sanctified wine unknown to mewith a grimace— it shall be denied utterly , for the sake of seemliness .

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.p: But in the days of trial to come , will not the lord Ozias have need of the licence ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: grandlyFriend , return ye to Joachim and say to him that the Lord has delivered Bethulia from the Assyrians by the subtlety of his servant Ozias .

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.p: amazedWhat says my lord ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Yea , this night the head of Holofernes is set on a spear in the square before the temple , and the Assyrians flee one from another in disorder , and my hosts are about to descend upon them and rend them to pieces where they stand foolishly in the valley .

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.p: But this thing is marvellous beyond the understanding of man !

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: It is indeed marvellous .

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.p: And when Joachim enquires of me who hath taken Holofernes the great captain to behead him , and by what device , what shall I answer to Joachim ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: You will answer that Ozias , knowing the weakness of Holofernes , sent down to him secretly a woman , a certain Judith of Bethulia , and upon the counsel of Ozias the woman by wiles compassed the death of Holofernes as I have told you .

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.p: It is a tale which fathers shall tell to their children , and to their children 's children , and men shall wonder thereat for all time . And now your servant will say to you a thing which has not been told to him but which his ear has heard . It was said among the mighty that if my lord Ozias should save Judea from the heathen , he would receive notable advancement and be raised up among the great ones of the land .Ozias bows .Yet will Joachim not be astonished , for it was spoken in Jerusalem that among all the Israelites there is none like the lord Ozias for cunning and obstinacy in defence .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: nettledNevertheless it is meet that Joachim should be astonished , for with five thousand have I set at naught one hundred and two and thirty thousand , and in the chronicles of Israel there is written down no deed to match the delivery of Judea from the Assyrians .

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.p: The God of Israel hath saved Israel .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: The God of Israel hath save Israel ,— by my hand . Go ye , and when you have eaten and drunk , set ye forth again for Jerusalem .

div.stage: The Messenger salutes and exit , L .
Throughout this scene excited and joyous men and women frequently pass the street in twos and threes .
Dawn is breaking and the torches begin to pale .
Enter Haggith and Ingur from the house .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Where art thou going ?

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: Lord Ozias , I came up from the valley to bring water , and to give tidings . Now I go down again to the valley with Ingur and his men to seek out my mistress , and to take new raiment to her , and lead her to the city ; for since the Israelites are fallen upon the Assyrians , my mistress is no longer in danger .

div.stage: Enter Achior .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Slave , who hath dared to loose thee ?

sp.speaker: ACHIOR
sp.p: There was none left to guard , and I came forth .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: to a soldierSeize this fellow and bind him with fetters .

div.stage: The torches are by this time extinguished .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: Lord , it cannot be so . For the lady Judith commanded me to bring Achior also , for her protection , seeing that the youth came from the Assyrians at the bidding of the God of Israel to give comfort to Israel , and for a sign to my mistress .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: after a pauseI also will go with you , for it is right that the governor should do honour to the lady Judith .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: My mistress commanded me to say to the lord Ozias that he should remain in the city to prepare for her a welcome .She points to the gates and Achior gladly moves forward . She takes Ingur by the ear .Bestir thy legs , booby !

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: The subtlety of women is past knowing .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: at the gates , maliciouslyIt may be . But would the lord Ozias invite the displeasure of my mistress ? It is day . Let my lord sit in the sun .

div.stage: CURTAIN .

div.head: SCENE II

stage.stage: Charmis is alone at the open gates . Glimpses are caught of the people beyond the gates .

sp.speaker: TIME
sp.p: Afternoon of the same day .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: entering to Charmis , at the gatesThey say there is now much water in Bethulia .

sp.speaker: CHARMIS
sp.p: Seeing that I have toiled mightily seven hours this day in charge of six score crazy carriers to carry water up from the wells ! Would that Ozias had granted me a whip to sharpen their brains ! And now Ozias hath left me in charge of the gates .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: Where is Ozias , and what does he do ?

sp.speaker: CHARMIS
sp.p: He stands here beyond the gates to receive Judith and the women who have gone forth to meet her .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: What is the deed of Judith ?The noise of an approaching procession is heard . Charmis , ignoring Chabris , goes a little outside the gates to watch . Chabris continues in a louder voice .The streets of the city are empty . I say the streets of the city are empty .

lg.l: Dodderer ! The whole city is afoot on the hill-side , and all the
Assyrians left alive are fled in panic into the East .

sp.speaker: CHABRIS
sp.p: Then I will return to my house and drink again . No ! I will remain , and my eyes shall regard the women , as of old .

div.stage: Enter through the gates a procession of women ( including Rahel ) , waving branches . At the end of the procession come Haggith and Ingur , and finally Judith , with Achior on one hand , and Ozias on the other . Townspeople and soldiers , garlanded , follow the procession .
BALLET .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: to JudithO daughter , blessed be thou above all the women of the earth . Thou art the exaltation of Jerusalem and the great glory of Israel , for the Lord hath directed thee to the cutting off of the head of the chief of our enemies , and thou hast revenged our ruin .

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: So be it .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Holofernes came out of the mountains from the north , and his horsemen covered the hills ; and he bragged that he would burn up the borders of Israel , and kill her young men with the sword , and make the virgins as a spoil . But the Almighty Lord hath disappointed the Assyrians by the hand of a woman ; and my sandals ravished the eye of Holofernes , and my beauty took his mind prisoner , and the knife passed through his neck . Let all creatures serve the Lord !

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: So be it !

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Charmis , I appoint you to lead the people to the Temple , where are the banners of the Assyrians which we have captured this day , and each woman shall take a banner , and all shall return to this place before the house of the Lady Judith .

sp.speaker: CHARMIS
sp.p: swollen with prideI obey , lord Ozias .

div.stage: The procession begins to move away , L. Haggith displays her importance and bullies Ingur , who accompanies her .

sp.speaker: RAHEL
sp.p: to ChabrisWhat , grandad ! You are abroad once more !She takes him with her like a disobedient child .

div.stage: Exeunt , processionally , all except Judith , Ozias and Achior .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: to AchiorThou goest not with the people ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: to AchiorStay , I pray you , Achior .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: to Judith , with growing excitementI wish to speak privily with the lady Judith , now !

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Let us speak here .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Shall we not go into your house , you and I ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: My house is not ready to receive you , Ozias .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Let it be so . But before Achior I will not speak .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Achior , go into my house , and do honour to my dwelling , and repose in it .

sp.speaker: ACHIOR
sp.p: Gladly , O lady !Exit into the house .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: What is the urgency that oppresses you , Ozias , and why are you troubled in the hour of triumph ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: losing control of himselfWho is the heathen Achior that you should prefer him and make your mouth sweet to him ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Leave Achior , and let us come at once to the matter that presses .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Oh ! I will not speak smoothly for a pretence ! Thou knowest that my jealousy smokes against Achior . Yea , and against Holofernes also .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: But Holofernes is dead .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Before he went down to his place , didst thou not sin with him ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: As the Lord liveth , my countenance deceived him to his destruction , yet did he not shame me .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Blessed be our God !

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: But how does this matter touch thee , and what is my virtue in thy regard ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Let Holofernes suffice thee , and drive not me also to death with the softness of thy voice . Art thou not aware that the soul of my soul burns for thee and will not wait — the more so since thou hast done a mighty deed and art proved a woman beyond all women ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Nay ! I have done naught ; but the Lord hath saved Israel by thy hand .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: What is this humbleness ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: AS I came towards the city with Achior , the messenger from Jerusalem met us in the way , and he was full to bursting of the word of Ozias , and that Ozias had delivered Israel , and that what I did I did by thy device and at thy command . But the messenger in speaking knew not that he spoke to Judith , and I let him go .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Judith ——

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Yet it seems to me that thou wast ignorant of all that which I went out to do , and my plan was hidden from thee .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: powerfully persuasiveHearken to me , Judith . I swear it was for thee that I boasted . My aim was that thy mighty deed should gain preferment in Jerusalem . But thou art a woman and therefore preferment is not for thee . Yet now by reason of my boasting I shall be greatly advanced and lifted up , and in all Judea there will be none higher than me , and thus wilt thou also be advanced and lifted up .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: I desire no preferment .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: But I would have it in thy behalf ; and my appetite is double . I rage for glory and dominion , and I rage also for thee . And I will offer thee glory and dominion , for I seek these things as a gift to thy beauty . And if I cannot lay them on thy lap my heel shall spurn mankind and I will tread it to dust . My desires are terrible ; they will not be withstood ; they consume me daily , but daily I am renewed . I am on fire , but by the fierceness of the fire I am strengthened . I was conceived for greatness and my mother bore me for mastery , and the huge earth shall shake with the terror of my commands .... And I am held between thy fingers .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: I deny not thy greatness .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Surely thou canst not . For thou too art great . And my greatness yearns to thine .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Wilt thou listen ?

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: I hear .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: With this greatness of thine goes deceit and laxity of mind .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Yet when thou didst thy mighty deed didst thou not deceive cruelly ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: I deceived not for myself , but for Israel ; and my guile was for the glory of God . But thy heart is set only upon advancement and power , which is corruption .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Judith , canst thou not lift thy thoughts beyond good and evil , and canst thou not contemplate the marvellous greatness of man ? I will abase myself before none but thee , and in my ear there is no commandment but thine ; and all other decrees will I mock . I would have thee in marriage , and I would have no other but thee . Wilt thou take me to thee , and wilt thou yield thyself without fear to the terrible flame of my love ? For thus shalt thou fulfil thyself and me . But give heed before thou answerest , and know that if thou turnest from me , I will make all the nations of the earth to tremble with my fury .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Thou art great also in thy loving .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Once thou didst love me .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Nay ! I but looked upon thee in kindness . But now I will not go to thee in marriage .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: half admiringThou art not then afraid of my wrath !

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: I am Judith .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: with a fresh access of violenceThou hungerest for Achior . Wouldst thou marry a heathen , thou a Hebrew woman ?

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: And thou , if I had not accomplished the will of the Lord , and if thou hadst been carried to Babylon as thou saidst , wouldst thou not have denied the Most High and gone after other gods ? But Achior believeth in our God , and this day will be joined into the house of Israel .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: savagely scornfulWhat is Achior but a simpleton !

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: It may be . But I love him and he shall rule me ... for he came hither for a sign from the Lord .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: savagely resentfulOh ! If I did not love thee , would I not undo thee !

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: Thou ! Thou art Ozias , but I am she who cut off the head of a mightier than thou , even Holofernes in his tent . Go thy ways and fulfil greatness . As for me I will remain obediently in my house , and truth and righteousness shall reign in my house .

div.stage: The procession returns , the women bearing the banners of the Assyrians . Achior enters from the house .
Judith is crowned with olives .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: And now let the priests and the elders enter with me into my house , and Achior shall follow them , so that he may be received into Israel , and I will be betrothed to him with all the ceremonies of the law , for he came to me as a messenger from God . And when the marriage has been performed , I will submit myself to him as a wife to her husband .

sp.speaker: HAGGITH
sp.p: And let Ingur also be received into Israel , for he has repented of his idolatries . And he shall be my husband , yet shall he not rule me .

sp.speaker: OZIAS
sp.p: Brethren , hearken ! This night I go to Jerusalem , for I am called to higher things , because I have delivered Israel . And I shall not return to this little city ; but ye will have tidings of me in the years to come , and ye will say proudly to the strangers within your gates : He was a Bethulian and once he ruled over us .

sp.speaker: JUDITH
sp.p: The lord Ozias is called to greatness . Peace go with him .

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: So be it .

div.stage: CURTAIN .
